Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?

4hr
I think this course was very informative. I enjoyed many of the guest lecturers and felt that we really were able to dive deeply into many different cancer types.

This course is okay. It was a little disappointing since I expected much more. There's a lot of experts that come in to speak, which provides students with an abundant source of information. However, lectures don't tie well with each other and seem very scattered. It's hard for students to know how to study. The assignments are also not very stimulating. This course wasn't really about epidemiology of cancer. It was more about different types of cancers.
I like that the course incorporated lectures from various experts in the field. This kept class interesting and engaging. Very manageable workload with interesting assignments.

Having guest lecturers that are experts in their field is a strength of the course, though it can be somewhat challenging to know how to study for the class since there are so many different lecturers/lecture styles. Having a midterm may be beneficial to get a clearer sense of study strategies before taking the final exam. The three class assignments were interesting and of an appropriate level, but I found that the instructions for the assignments were somewhat vague and open to interpretation. Having clearer instructions would improve the course.
great

There are a lot of speakers who bring in various perspectives which is fantastic.

The weakness is that sometimes the topics can be a bit dry. Also, there's a lot of material and it is a little unclear how in depth the instructor wants us to go. It has a broad range of very biological to grand scheme of cancer epidemiology.
Good overview of cancer epi

I think the weakness of this course is that it doesn't require students to think critically about the information provided. Much of the course is fact memorization along with simply presenting information in the form of an essay. It might be more valuable to have practical application of the course material, in the terms of writing hypothetical policy. The readings were interesting if cancer is something of the student's interest, but otherwise, there wasn't much in the course that would keep most students engaged. I would assume that most students probably came to class without doing the readings because it was easy to go through the course without readings. The information was interesting, but I think more could be done to get the students to apply their knowledge.

This is a great course for an introduction to cancer epidemiology. It is lecture-based with guest speakers almost every week. It was interesting to learn about different cancers from experts in the field.

This course is a good overview of the different types of cancers however it is poor in its design. We had guest lecturers come in every week but there was no cohesiveness and this added up to a lot of studying for the final. Dr Cartmel's instructions are extremely vague and do not help in preparing for the final or the papers assigned during the class. The strength was the assignment on grey literature since it was very practical and fun to do.

This course provides a big picture of the cancer epidemiology in the US and in the world. It illustrates some underlying reasons for the fluctuation of the incidence rate and mortality rate. The introduction to each cancer site could be more organized.
This course was excellent. it provided me with knowledge about the epidemiology of cancer, as well as knowledge about the specific pathology of cancer from a clinical standpoint. I learned so much.
Good introduction to cancer epi. If you're an MD then likely overlap/refresher of stuff from medical school. Good guest speakers.

While the material presented was interesting, I expected a more thorough discussion of epidemiological methods used to study cancer at the population level. This was more of a "topics in cancer epidemiology" course, since we received a relatively brief and disconnected overview of many different types of cancers from many different perspectives. I believe the course would have much more value if there were more thorough discussion of methods and study design. We could then draw connections from how a certain method or design used for one cancer can or cannot be used for another. Clinical information such as tumor staging is less useful for public health scientists, and such clinical details seem outside of the scope of a "cancer epidemiology" course.

Additionally, I think the final exam was an inappropriate evaluation for this course. Not only was the exam antithetical to what we had been told about it ("no questions on specific clinical trials, mostly general concepts, etc."), but we had not had any other examinations in the course up to that point. As a result, the final exam felt entirely out of the blue, covered a huge variety in topics, and I came away feeling frustrated and like I had not prepared sufficiently (though I had been to nearly every class, paid attention, and reviewed my notes thoroughly in advance). I would consider replacing the exam with another paper or presentation, since, in my opinion, the exam did not benefit the student in any way. Perhaps proposing an epidemiologic study design would be a good final project.

Strengths: Incredibly interesting material and very knowledgeable speakers and professor!  Great overview of major dilemmas facing cancer diagnoses and treatment. 

Weaknesses: Difficult to know what would be covered on the final.  In the future, it would be helpful if midterm assignments were similar to the final.
I enjoyed this course very much. Very dynamic and covered a lot of interesting material.
interesting, very disorganized

The course has clear strengths in the amount of material it covers and who covers them. Experts in all forms of cancer from all over Yale come and and lecture alongside Dr. Cartmel to truly give students a comprehensive look at cancer in the U.S. and internationally, both currently and over time. I think the main weakness comes in the assignments we had to do, but only in how they were returned/graded. I think just the speed in which things were returned made it hard to know how you were doing in the class with good notice, and the grading scale was somewhat ambiguous. I think if Dr. Cartmel explained her grading system a bit more on day one and kept us up to date more on the process of grading, everything would be a lot better on this front. That being said, if things are kept the way they are now, everything would still operate smoothly.

this is a very good course with a lot to learn. The instructor and guest speakers give fun classes with intuitive materials. I suggest to make the slides on canvas more organized. for example, order slides by lecture numbers and align the slides names with the syllabus.
Learn about a variety of cancers and how each of them affects population health.
Brenda is a wonderful professor. She is kind and passionate. She always makes herself available to you if you need her for anything.

Very nice instructor but can be hard to get to know. Comments/grades provided on assignments can also be very vague and subjective. Dr. Cartmel responds to emails very promptly, which is nice. The instructions for the assignments are also vague.
Brenda is great! She is so kind, she made the course material very approachable and interesting.

Professor Cartmel is passionate and engaging. She is also receptive to students and makes herself available to them. The only comment I have for improvement is that sometimes the pace of the lectures is too slow and we do not finish all the slides during class.
Great. Professor provided students with helpful and timely feedback.
She's a really nice professor!
Good and brought in a great variety of speakers.

Professor Cartmel is clearly passionate about what she does, but I think the primary challenge of her course is that she has to communicate information that she is extremely interested in to a class full of students that may be taking the class purely for a credit. The lectures need some more engagement and animation besides mostly talking from lecture slides. There's so much cool information to be gotten from cancer epidemiology. The trick is communicating it in a way that exemplifies that, potentially inspiring students to join the field.
Dr. Cartmel is kind and supportive. It is obvious she cares about her students.

Dr Cartmel is very sweet and helpful to students. However, her instructions are extremely unclear for most assignments and the final. She is not great at giving feedback either. Her teaching would be a lot better if there was more organization and clarity in the assignments, and transparency of grading scale and thresholds. There is no way of knowing how well you are doing in the class based on a scale since this information is not revealed to students. Her lectures are nice, however, once again, there is too much breath of knowledge rather than depth.
Prof. Cartmel is very nice and patient. Her illustration for the cancer incidence, mortality and the underlying reasons was clear and thorough.
Dr. Cartmel was an extremely knowledgeable instructor who explained things incredibly well.
Very nice and helpful Professor. Brought in good guest speakers. Liked structure of course.

The instructor is highly knowledgeable and approachable. I would have liked for her to share more of her expertise in conducting studies of cancer as well as her rich analytical experience. I feel that the course does not take full advantage of the instructor's depth of knowledge and skill.
super knowledgeable and lectures were very interesting and clear!

Dr. Cartmel is a great instructor. She did an excellent job in selecting speakers and assigning a variety of projects to help us learn and think critically about the material. Highly enjoyed her course!
most instruction from guests

Dr. Cartmel is well connected and very knowledgeable in the field. She is very easy to speak to and is quite encouraging. Her lectures are in depth and she does way more than just read from slides, inviting students to truly engage with the material, which is pivotal for such an important topic.
I like the way Dr. Cartmel teaches.
Dr. Cartmel's teaching style is very calm, like gently telling a story.

I would recommend this course to someone who is interested in learning facts and statistics about various types of cancer. Sometimes the presentations can get very biological. Also be prepared for many guest lectures.

Average course. Not really what I was expecting, but good for if you want to know more about different types of cancers. Just don't expect it to get into epidemiology concepts. It's more of a general overview/introduction to cancers, treatment, and detection.

This course is a broad overview of cancer in the U.S. (organized by cancer type). I would recommend the class to a student wanting to learn more about different cancers in a qualitative format. The course does not emphasize epidemiological methods for studying cancer. If students are more interested in methodology and working with cancer data, this may not be the right course for them.
great. will recommend
I would recommend it for someone who wants to learn more about cancer epidemiology as an overview.
Great for getting a good overview of cancer epi.

If you are interested in cancer, this class could be good for you. There is plenty of reading that would make anyone well informed on the subjects covered in this course. However, anyone could read the papers provided in this class, and you don't necessarily need the class to get information about cancer epidemiology. In all honesty, if you are interested in cancer, I would recommend reading the literature on your own time, which is a bit of a contradiction to my first line. However, I think the joy of taking a class should be in the fact that it is taught by a professor with years of experience and expertise in the field. I think the professor, rather than the coursework should be inspiring to the students. If Professor Cartmel injected more of her life experience into the course, in a way that demonstrated how passionate she is about what she studies, the course could be so much more than what it is. As of now, the class is pretty standard, and doesn't stand out from your usual class that you would take for credit.

I do recommend this course for students who want a broad understanding of cancer epidemiology. It's a fairly easy course with 2-3 assignments and a final exam. It was interesting, and I enjoyed the material.

The course is like a dive into the different cancer types but I would not really recommend it to another student since the classroom environment did not add a lot to my learning (other than the cancer grey literature assignment). If you want to learn about different cancers, another way to do so is just read the lecture slides and network with professors who work in the cancer world.
I would recommend this course.
Would recommend!

I would call this course "topics in cancer epidemiology." I felt it was almost more of a seminar series than an actual course on cancer epidemiology. I would recommend it if they had little to no knowledge of cancer and just wanted to test the waters. I would not recommend it to a student looking to learn more about how to conduct studies of cancer at the population level.

very interesting course and covers as described: the epidemiology of cancer. 

would recommend, but understand that the course covers A LOT of clinical information from doctors.
I would highly recommend this course to other students interested in learning basic concepts about cancer epidemiology and meeting local scholars and practitioners who specialize in cancer research.
interesting, prepare for final exam - it will be heavily based on trick and detailed questions despite the advice

The course is as it is named. You will learn all about cancer. Whether it is prevention, physiology, naming, medical treatments, etc., it will be covered and you will leave the class surely feeling like you can speak relatively confidently on most all cancers affecting the US and most of the world today.
This is a good introduction course for students who are interested in cancer research.
fulfill CDE core curriculum. the workload is good for 2nd year MPH.
